Award.AwardTitle: Resolution of Important Remaining Puzzles in Conjugated Polymer Photophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This project is designed to provide a detailed understanding of photophysics in conjugated polymers used for optoelectronic applications. Transient absorption and delayed luminescence experiments are performed on solutions and films of electroluminescent polymers to address the root cause of the decrease in fluorescence quantum yield in films, the branching ratio for recombination of charge carriers to form singlet states and the origin of magnetic field effects in organic light-emitting diodes. In donor-acceptor blends relevant to fabrication of solar cells from conjugated polymers, time-delayed field collection experiments to quantify charge photogeneration efficiency and transient absorption to ascertain whether energy transfer plays an important role in organic photovoltaics.
Nontechnical: The research has implications for the design of materials and device structures for solar cells, optically pumped film lasers, lighting, display devices and spintronic technologies based on processable conjugated polymer materials. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in the research acquire interdisciplinary training in areas as diverse as condensed matter physics, optics, materials science, analytical chemistry and device engineering. Hands-on educational modules demonstrating how conjugated polymers can change color and enable light detection as in solar cells are developed for middle and secondary school students in collaboration with a local high school science teacher and disseminated on the Internet

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our project was to study properties of luminescent polymers that can be used in optical and electronic applications such as displays, lighting, biomolecular tagging for medical imaging.  The materials studied are similar to the organic materials now used in recently launched OLED displays such as the Samsung S-6 cell phone and the Apple watch. However, the polymeric versions of these materials  can in principle be processed from solution so that more cost effective manufacturing techniques such as screen and ink jet printing may be feasible. A main obstacle to using the polymeric light emitters is their luminescence efficiency which is found to depend strongly on how the polymer chains organize. One thrust of our work is devoted to understanding why this is the case and what strategies can be used to inhibit formation of poorly emitting morphologies. A second line of investigation is to determine whether a recent hypothesis that the polymers are advantaged over the current materials in terms of their propensity to form “singlet states”, the more efficient of two possible states formed by recombination of electrically injected charges, is correct. In both cases, we have taken a unique approach to elucidating the underlying science.

In the case of looking at the reasons for low luminescence efficiency in polymer films, we have showed that reductions in order are helpful and identified specific red chromophores that are responsible for reduced luminescence. We have also showed that these chromophores can be selectively destroyed and are investigating whether that is a viable strategy to make improved films for light-emitting devices. In the case of determining whether polymers can have high ratios of singlet state formation, we have studied a surprising phenomenon called “delayed luminescence” that reflects how charges recombine without the complications of fabricating and calibrating devices. We have enabled both the efficient and inefficient states of the material to emit light so that we can calibrate the relative amounts of each that is formed. Further work is required to reach a definite conclusion but we have at least showed that the conventional wisdom that these states are formed in ratio of 1:3 is not correct.

The fact that electronics and lighting can be made using organic polymers has more than technological implications. Because the processing is relatively easy, it can be done by secondary school science students and we have developed hands on materials to make solar cells and organic light-emitting diodes (see attached image). Moreover, we have worked with teacher Thomas Bertrand from a local school district to make these modules practical from the perspective of safety, cost and compatibility with standard high school chemistry curricula. We understand that impact will depend on teachers’ ability to integrate them with the relatively rigid standards now in place. These demonstrations are visually attractive and we have found them to be appealing and capture students’ imaginations in our early experience with them. We are in the process of making full documentation including procedures, purchasing lists from standard vendors familiar to high school teachers and discussion of how these activities fit into the chemistry curriculum.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/15/2015
Modified by: Lewis J Rothberg
